8.7.17  12:48 am   8.6.17  3:59 pm  8.5.17  3:21 pm RE: RE: bilabial trill and oven display: I've never met anyone else who can do this! I try to explain it to people but they can't seem to do it. They probably don't believe me that it's real.

This happens because some lights flicker with the AC power at 50 or 60 Hz, and some of the segments are out of phase with the others. So if you vibrate your head up and down at about the same frequency, you see some lights appear to be higher or lower than others, depending whether your head is at the top or bottom of its vibration when that light flickers.

I find it works best with LED Christmas lights, but oven displays are pretty good too.

8.6.17  8:32 pm   i just. i love it when picked or plucked strings sound SOAPY. you can hear it on a bright acoustic guitar but... even more on a banjo or mandolin. there's something about the satisfying, slippery but solid texture of that sound that makes me think of soap. even dragging a pick across a string sounds like what it feels like to run your fingernail over a bar of soap. all the little stops and starts. mmmm. yummy right

8.6.17  3:10 pm   So I recently moved to a state where ive noticed that most people say "what's good" as a greeting. Where I'm from originally , most people say "what's up" instead. But when people ask me "what's good" I feel like I shouldn't say "not much" or "nothing" cause that seems like it would be very depressing. "What's good?"... "Not much"....that makes me seem sad. 8.6.17  1:17 pm   Do you ever have a very specific idea of what you want (maybe like a specific graphic, visual effect, sound effect/tone, etc) but you don't know how to actually go about executing your idea? For reference, there's blogs and vlogs but I want to make condensed what I'll call "slogs" (sound blogs) where I record all the sounds around me (speaking, car sounds, music, radio, footsteps, cooking sounds, animal sounds, literally any sound that can be picked up by a mic) for 24 hours.. then I went to take that 24 hour recording, splice it into 10 second fragments (or maybe 5 seconds or 15 seconds, haven't decided) and layer all the spliced clips on top of eachother and play it all simultaneously so you have this cacophony of 24 hours worth of sounds smashed into 10 seconds... but I don't think recording softwares can handle that much audio files, and cpu or phone batteries don't last 24 hours.... I really want to do this, but I don't see how it can be done... . and it 's wildly frustrating for me.
